awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Comparative Study of Desert and Non-desert Rodent Kidneys
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to combine experimental and mathematical modeling techniques to investigate aspects of the renal transport and dynamics in the Munich-Wistar rat and kangaroo rat kidneys. In many rodent kidneys, the renal pelvic walls undergo peristaltic contractions, which cause bolus flow down the papillary collecting duct. The project will use immunohistochemical and videomicroscopy techniques to investigate the impacts of peristaltic contractions on medullary architecture and maximal urine concentration. Pelvic wall peristalsis generates complex fluid dynamics and likely has a substantial impact on water and solute transport in the loops of Henle, collecting ducts and blood vessels. Thus, mathematical models will be developed to simulate how the interactions between the collecting duct epithelium and the traveling bolus change tubular fluid composition in the face of peristaltic waves. The fluid-structure interactions will be modeled as an immersed boundary problem, and an accurate numerical method will be developed for the axissymmetric cylindrical coordinates.

This project will use mathematical analysis and computational techniques to answer a number of basic and important questions in renal physiology: How do the peristaltic contractions of the renal papilla impact the concentrating mechanism of the kidney? How do the anatomic differences between the kangaroo rat and the laboratory rat lead to the ability of the kangaroo rat to produce urine that is twice as concentrated? The answers to those questions are crucial in gaining an overall understanding of kidney functions.

por.por_cntn:
If one is stranded in the ocean for days, should one drink the sea water to quench one's thirst? The answer depends on whether the subject is a person (don't!) or a rat (drink away!). The reason is that the osmolality (i.e., total solute concentration) of sea water is higher than the maximum urine osmolality that can be produced by a human. In contrast, a rat can produce a urine twice as concentrated as sea water. The kangaroo rat is even more amazing---it lives in the desert and survives only dry seeds. It may be hard to believe, but the mechanism by which these rodents produce highly concentrated urine is not well understood. Thus, a goal of this project is to use mathematical analysis and computational techniques to answer a number of basic and important questions in renal physiology: How do the peristaltic contractions of the renal papilla impact the concentrating mechanism of the kidney? How do the anatomic differences between the kangaroo rat and the laboratory rat lead to the ability of the kangaroo rat to produce urine that is several times more concentrated? The answers to those questions are crucial in an overall understanding of kidney functions.

 

Given our vastly different living environments, perhaps the inter-species differences between people and rodents, or even between the regular rat and kangaroo rat, aren?t all that surprising. But even between the males and females of a given species, there are important differences in kidney and its related functions (e.g., blood pressure control). For instance, men are more likely than women to suffer from high blood pressure and its fatal cardiovascular consequences. But despite this well-known sex difference, men and women are often prescribed the same blood pressure medication, leading to better outcomes in men. Thus, another goal of this project is to use mathematical analysis and computational techniques to answer questions regarding sex differences in kidney function: How do sex differences in kidney and other systems affect blood pressure control in men and women? Why are some blood pressure medications more effective for women, and others are more effective for men? The answers to these questions have important health benefits, given that one in three American adults suffer from high blood pressure.

 

In the course of this project, our group have made significant progress in some of the above questions, many of which are challenging ones that have puzzled scientists for decades. To investigate the sex differences in blood pressure control, we developed sex-specific computational models of the renin-angiotensin system (a non-sex hormonal system that regulates blood pressure and fluid balance), and then incorporated those models into big, sex-specific models of long-term blood pressure regulation, which include also the kidney (of course), heart, and relevant parts of the nervous system. Based on our simulation results, we hypothesize that the sex differences in blood pressure regulation may be attributed, in large part, to the sex differences in the renal sympathetic nervous system. And men and women?s differing responses to some of the blood pressure medication may be explained by the effect of a product of the renin-angiotensin system on a major blood vessel.

 

In addition to sex differences in blood pressure control, we also made progress in understanding inter-species differences in kidney function. Specifically, we have combined experimental and mathematical modeling techniques to investigate aspects of kidney functions in the regular lab rat and kangaroo rat kidneys. Here we focus on a mechanism called ?peristalsis.? In many rodent kidneys, the renal pelvic walls undergo peristaltic contractions, which cause fluid to travel down the renal tubule in bolus. Our experimental collaborator at U Arizona used immunohistochemical and videomicroscopy techniques to measure the frequency of peristaltic contractions, and how urinary output changes accordingly. Our job is to incorporate their experimental findings into a computational model of peristaltic contractions. In particular, we want to capture the complex fluid dynamics generated by the pelvic wall peristalsis and the effects on water and solute transport in the kidney. Indeed, this is an example of fluid-structure interactions problems, which are known to be challenging to simulate and analyze. We have made substantial progress by developing a sophisticated numerical method to compute solution of the model equations.

 

In summary, the overall intellectual merit of this research is that more complete understanding may be gained of the regulatory mechanisms of the rodent kidneys, and the comparative approach may yield the discovery of basic physiological principles in water homeostasis. Beyond renal physiology, project research has contributed to the field of computational mathematics: an accurate and efficient numerical method will be developed to solve fluid-structure interactions problems. The method can be used to simulate other biofluid, including blood flow, food mixing and chyme movement in intestine, transport of spermatozoa in cervical canal, transport of bile in bile ducts, etc.
